name: Cockapoo
coat_color: Black, White, Buff, Cream, Apricot, Red, Chocolate, Parti-color, Phantom, Sable, Tricolor, Merle, Roan
coat_length: A Cockapoo’s coat can range in length and texture, from short and curly to long and wavy, to somewhere in between.
ears: The long, floppy Cockapoo ears hang at the top of their head.
eyes: Their round, expressive eyes are often brown, and convey the breed's kind and perceptive disposition.
nose: Cockapoos usually have a brown or black nose, depending on the color of their coat.
tail: Cockapoos typically have a medium-length tail. Their tail is sometimes docked like their Cocker Spaniel and Poodle parents, though this is a controversial practice that many groups, including the American Veterinary Medical Association, oppose.
best_for: The Cockapoo, a cute cross between a Poodle and a Cocker Spaniel, is renowned for being gregarious and energetic. Part zoomie champion, part cuddle bug, this curly coated charmer is totally loyal to their favorite people and loves to meet new friends.
breed_intro:
Prepare yourself for a lifetime of wet kisses, tail wags, and unceasing affection—your Cockapoo is about to win your heart.

Cockapoos are a mix between a Cocker Spaniel and one of the three types of Poodle:

	• A Toy Cockapoo has a Toy Poodle parent and often weighs under 12 pounds.
A Mini Cockapoo has a Miniature Poodle parent, often weighing 12–20 pounds. This is the most common Cockapoo size.
A Standard Cockapoo has a Standard Poodle parent and tips the scale at 20 pounds or more.

No matter their size, Cockapoo dogs are full of personality, and will gladly greet any new companion (whether they are four-legged or two-legged) and insist they join in the fun.
appearance_description: The Cockapoo is a small- to medium-sized bundle of fluff with a cuddly, teddy bear–like look. Their soft wavy or curly coat; round, soulful eyes; and floppy ears make them extra adorable. Always full of energy and tail wags, these happy pups bring joy everywhere they go.
temperament_description:
Cockapoos are known for being happy, caring, and people-oriented, and they’re at their best when surrounded by family.

As social and friendly dogs, they’re great with kids, welcoming to strangers, and usually get along well with other pets. All of these traits make Cockapoo puppies a great pick for first-time pet parents.

Though they’re descended from working dogs (the Poodle and Cocker were both originally hunting dogs), Cockapoos are happier living the unemployed life. This way, they can focus their energy on the family they love. (That’s you!)

Regular strolls, belly rubs, and a comfortable spot on the sofa are non-negotiables for this family dog.
care_description:
Adorable, active, and people-oriented puppies, Cockapoos flourish in homes with lots of love and activity.

Though they require regular grooming, exercise, and affection to remain happy and healthy, Cockapoos are often easy to train due to their smarts and eager-to-please personality.
grooming_description:
As a Poodle mix, Cockapoos have been dubbed a “hypoallergenic” dog (though there’s really no such thing). And while it’s true that Cockapoo dogs who take after their Poodle parent might not shed much, some with more Cocker Spaniel–like coats can still shed and trigger allergies in certain people.

No matter which of their parent’s coat they inherit, Cockapoos require regular grooming to be happy and healthy. 

Here’s a glimpse at a typical Cockapoo grooming routine:

	• Brushing: To avoid tangles and mats, it’s best to brush your Cockapoo every day. Use a comb or brush that’s suitable for curly coats, like a slicker brush.
Bathing: Bathe your dog with a mild dog shampoo every four to six weeks.
Clipping: To maintain their coat, most Cockapoos require a trim every six to eight weeks. For the popular "puppy cut" or other hairstyle, many pet parents use a professional groomer.

	• Along with your Cockapoo’s haircuts, a groomer can also take care of other tasks like bathing and nail trimming.

Ear cleaning: Use a veterinarian-approved ear cleaner once a week to maintain their ears, keeping them healthy and dry.
Nail trimming: To avoid irritation, overgrowth, or cracking, trim your Cockapoo’s nails every two to four weeks. (When you hear their nails clacking across the floor, they need a trim.)
Dental care: To help prevent dental disease, try to brush their teeth at least twice a week (but every day is best). You can also give your Cockapoo veterinarian-recommended dental chews or oral hygiene products to keep their pearly whites healthy.
training_description:
If you’ve never trained a dog before, a Cockapoo might be a good pick. These dogs are bright and want to make their human happy—two traits that make them highly trainable.

But that’s not to say training will be a breeze. Like all dogs, Cockapoos need positive reinforcement, patience, and consistency to learn. Start with obedience basics like sit, stay, and come. From there, your Cockapoo can learn fun new tricks.

Early, consistent socialization is also important for these fluffy companions; it builds their confidence and ensures they grow into well-adjusted adults who get along well with people, children, and other animals.

Regularly exposing your Cockapoo puppy to new experiences, sounds, sights, and interactions will shape them into friendly, sociable companions. It also reduces the risk of anxiety or fearfulness later in life.
diet_nutrition:
Cockapoos do best on a high-quality, balanced dog food that’s appropriate for their age, size, and activity level. Look for a formula that’s AAFCO-compliant to ensure it meets established nutritional standards. (Don’t worry, your vet can help you find the perfect dog food.)

It’s best to feed adult Cockapoos two measured meals a day to help maintain a healthy weight and prevent overeating. Cockapoo puppies might need to eat more frequently (maybe three or four meals every day).

Always keep fresh water available and talk to your vet about the best feeding plan for your dog.
exercise_description:
Cockapoos are lively, playful dogs who need 30–60 minutes of exercise each day to stay happy and healthy. Without enough activity, they can get bored—and that’s when mischief happens!

A couple of daily walks, combined with some fun playtime and training sessions, usually does the trick. Cockapoos love playing fetch and chasing toys, and they might also enjoy dog sports that tap into both their smarts and energy, like agility and dock diving.

Mental stimulation is just as important as physical exercise, so puzzle toys and games that challenge your dog’s brain are a big win. With the right mix of movement and engagement, your Cockapoo will be a happy, tail-wagging companion.
ideal_environment:
Cockapoos are adaptable and can thrive almost anywhere, from small city apartments to rural homes with sprawling acreage. The type of home doesn’t matter as long as their needs for daily exercise, mental stimulation, and grooming are met. A fenced yard is a good perk, but having one isn’t necessary if you regularly take your pup outside for walks and playtime.

They're happiest with active, affectionate pet parents who involve their furry family member in everyday activities.
health_description:
The average Cockapoo lifespan is 14–18 years, and they’re typically healthy dogs. But all dogs, Cockapoos included, can develop certain health conditions during life.

	• Ear infections: A Cockapoo’s long, floppy ears are more likely to develop ear infections than breeds with pricked-up ears. Chat with your vet if you notice signs of an infection (like redness, debris buildup, or odor)—they’ll give guidance on how to treat the infection and prevent the condition in the future.
Allergies and skin problems: If your Cockapoo gets recurring ear infections, it may be due to allergies. Allergies in dogs can also cause skin irritation, redness, and itching. Talk to your vet if you notice any of these.
Hip dysplasia: This hereditary disorder arises when the hip joint fails to grow normally, which may result in arthritis and problems with movement. The risk of hip dysplasia may be decreased with weight management and joint supplements, though surgery is sometimes recommended.
Patellar luxation: Small- to medium-sized dogs frequently experience patellar luxation, a condition in which the kneecap slides out of position. Your vet may recommend surgery for severe cases.
Progressive retinal atrophy: PRA is a group of degenerative eye conditions that can eventually cause blindness. To lower the risk in puppies, ethical breeders frequently check for this hereditary disease.
Cataracts and glaucoma: As Cockapoos age, they may be more susceptible to eye conditions such cataracts and glaucoma. Keep up with regular veterinary exams for early detection.
Hypothyroidism: This hormonal imbalance can lead to weight gain, lethargy, and skin issues. It’s typically manageable with daily medication.
history_description:
Because the Cockapoo is a mixed breed, the dogs’ history is a little murky. The Cocker Spaniel-Poodle cross gained popularity with many other designer breeds, like the Goldendoodle and Labradoodle, in the 20th century. Bred to be a friendly, low-shedding companion, the Cockapoo quickly became a popular family pet.

While not recognized by the American Kennel Club, the breed is supported by clubs like the American Cockapoo Club, which promotes responsible breeding and standards.

faqs.question: How long do Cockapoos live?
faqs.answer: The typical Cockapoo lifespan is 14–18 years. Dogs with Toy Poodle lineage are likely to have a longer lifespan, because small dogs live longer than big dogs.

faqs.question: How big do Cockapoos get?
faqs.answer: A Cockapoo’s size depends on the size of their Poodle parent, but most Cockapoos are typically 12–22 pounds and 10–18 inches tall.

faqs.question: How much does a Cockapoo cost?
faqs.answer: Cockapoo puppies typically cost $800–$2,500, depending on factors like your breeder, where you live, and the dog’s lineage.

faqs.question: Is a Cockapoo a good family dog?
faqs.answer: Yes, Cockapoos make excellent family dogs. They’re affectionate, friendly, and gentle, making them especially well-suited for homes with children.

faqs.question: Cavapoo vs. Cockapoo: What’s the difference?
faqs.answer: Both Cavapoos and Cockapoos are Poodle mixes known for their sweet personalities and low-shedding coats. The key difference lies in their other parent breed: Cavapoos are a Cavalier King Charles Spaniel and Poodle mix, while Cockapoos are a cross between a Cocker Spaniel and Poodle.
